content: Established in the legislative branch, the Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti is tasked with specific duties. The Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti will examine the US Government's role in the coup, including impeding the democratic process, the resignation of President Aristide, and the fulfillment of obligations leading up to the coup. The Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti will investigate the US Government's actions regarding the overthrow of the democratically-elected Government of Haiti, including impeding international efforts to prevent the coup and influencing decisions at the United Nations Security Council. The Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti will investigate the extent of US assistance in supporting forces opposed to President Aristide, CIA involvement in the overthrow, and the impact of organizations like the International Republican Institute. The Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti will investigate the political and economic impact of the United States Government's decision to discontinue bilateral assistance to Haiti, as well as the broader implications for Haiti and the Caribbean region following the coup d'etat. The Commission may also examine the actions and representations of current and prior Administrations. The composition of the Commission for the investigation of the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti. The Commission for the investigation of the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti is composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders. Appointees must not be government officials and must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission for the investigation of the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti is composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders. Appointees must not be government officials and must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson shall be elected by the members of the Commission. Six members constitute a quorum, and vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 4. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold public hearings, meetings, and issue subpoenas as necessary for carrying out the Act. Public hearings must protect sensitive information, and public versions of reports must be released. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence, with disobedience punishable as civil contempt. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas in accordance with Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. It can also enter into contracts and request information from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. The General Services Administration is required to provide assistance to the Commission. The Commission may receive administrative support and services from General Services on a reimbursable basis. Additionally, other departments and agencies of the United States can provide services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as authorized by law. The Commission is allowed to accept gifts, use postal services, and dispose of donations. The Commission is allowed to have staff as per Section 5. The Chairperson of the Commission, with the Vice Chairperson, can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain regulations, with a pay limit. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can procure consultant services at rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 6. Compensation and Travel Expenses: Commission members may be compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members while on official business. SEC. 7. Security Clearances for Commission Members and Staff. SEC. 7. Security clearances for Commission members and staff require cooperation from Federal agencies to provide appropriate clearances, with access to classified information only granted with the necessary security clearance. SEC. 8. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to Congress and the President with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. Reports will be unclassified but may include a classified annex. SEC. 9. The Commission will terminate after submitting the final report. SEC. 9 states that the Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. SEC. 10 authorizes $5,000,000 for the Act in fiscal year 2005, with funds remaining available until the Commission terminates.
